Before we have a prayer, I'd like to share with you two special experiences that we had with Alan. Many knew him as a famous astronaut, most of you here as a friend, a colleague. We knew him more as a family man, as the devoted husband of Louise and the father of Laura, Julie and Alice. Our two daughters are the same age as his youngest two. They have always been the best of friends. Many times we saw Alan carrying the girl's dolls and tea sets from their house to ours and from ours to theirs. Our girls regarded Alan more as their friend's daddy and not as a world famous figure. So when he offered to fly them along with his three to Maine, to summer camp, we were thrilled for their sakes. We thought, just think what the children can tell their children, that Alan Shepard had flown them to Maine. As parents, that was our perspective. Having been a World War II B-17 pilot, I immediately asked him how are you going to manage five rambunctious little girls on the plane? He replied, it's very simple if they get restless I'll just go up to 10,000 feet and they will all go to sleep. We were at the local airport when they took off. They did have some engine trouble, so they flew directly to Hobby to get it repaired. Eventually, they took off for Maine. En route, they made other stops to refuel. Hours later, they arrived at Barnstable Airport in Massachusetts. Upon arrival, one of our little girls called me on the telephone and implored, oh daddy, please, please, next time can we go commercial? Now on to a more serious remembrance. After his return from the moon, my wife gingerly asked him Alan, he replied very solemnly, oh, yes, we thought about that. My friends, this is genuine courage and bravery. This is a tribute to the courage, bravery and heroism of Alan Shepard, and it is a tribute to all of the astronauts. These are brave and brave of the extraterrestrials. brave men, I am sure I speak for all Americans. We are proud of you, and we admire and appreciate your courage and bravery in this space effort. I could give no more sacred prayer than the following verses from the Bible. Psalms. Whither shall I go from thy spirit, or whither shall I flee from thy presence. If I ascend up into heaven, thou art there. If I make my bed in hell, behold, thou art there. If I take the wings of the morning and dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea, even there shall thy hand lead me and thy right hand shall hold me. As a young boy, who was a Sunday School student, Alan Shepard learned a prayer. His wife Louise wants his friends to hear this prayer, as he came to know it. She stated that this prayer had a profound influence on his life. This is the prayer by Mary Baker Eddy. Thy kingdom come. Let the reign of divine truth, life, and love be established in me and rule out of me all sin. And may thy word enrich the affections of all mankind and govern them. And from the scriptures. Good afternoon, Louise, the Sheppard family, ladies and gentlemen. It's wonderful to look out in that audience and almost recognize every face there. We're here this afternoon to remember Alan Sheppard as a friend and as a colleague, one who we all admire and will find impossible to replace. In 1959, when the United States decided to fly man in space, the newly chartered NASA needed a number of men to fly their Mercury spacecraft. The requirements for these aviators and soon-to-be-called astronauts were reasonable to be straightforward and unambiguous. unsurchemistry. A number of us in the Space Task Group had come from the world of airplane flight tests, and we recognized that we needed experienced test pilots who understood the rigors of testing the unknown and were accustomed to putting their lives in jeopardy every time they flew. They had to be prepared to do their job regardless of the threatening circumstances they might find themselves in. We also wanted them to understand the engineering design required of this new flying machine and to be able to participate in its development. Alan Shepard volunteered to be one of the men we were looking for. He came to this new challenge because in his mind spaceflight was the next step in man's quest to fly higher and faster and as a navy test pilot, this was his kind of business. He did not come into the space program looking for glory. Indeed, many of his peers looked with scorn on what they thought was a step backward in test flying and refused to consider themselves as test specimens for a highly experimental program with a questionable future. year. In fact, if you listen to the so called medical community who were advising NASA in 1959, the test pilots who were criticizing Project Mercury were justified in their evaluation. The great majority of the doctors believed that man's reaction to this new environment of zero gravity and a perfect vacuum would cause disorientation, nausea, loss of sight, and other dire ailments, and as a result, might be totally incapable of doing work, much less conducting the complex and intricate task we were expecting them to carry out. Fortunately, Bob Gilruth, and those of us who work for him, believed that a qualified test pilot, with proper training, could most likely accomplish the same tasks and space that they had been conducting in high performance airplanes. We wanted the men who were going to fly to be an integral part of the spacecraft, just as they had been in the airplanes they flew. As the first man flight approached, the competition for being first among the seven astronauts became very intense. As in any group greater than one, it was difficult to choose who should be selected. Bob Gilruth, a man who never received the proper credit for being the father of man in space flight, met with the astronauts and asked them to write a brief essay on who and why they should be chosen to fly the first flight, excluding themselves. From this interesting and provocative exercise, and with the advice and consent of his staff, He picked Alan Shepard to fly the first manned mercury redstone flight These were heady times And Alan already charged Doubled his efforts to train for the 15-minute sub-ortal flight Unfortunately Shepherd's flight had to be preceded by the flight of a chimpanzee Although we were six we successfully launched and recovered ham the hot engine of the redstone caused an early shutdown which precipitated an escape rocket separation, subjecting him to 17G and giving gave the false impression that the animal had failed to perform. The demand of further redstone testing and a requirement to test a large number of animals on the Johnsonville centrifuge postponed Shepherd's flight. Shepherd was extremely disappointed and agitated by the delay as was the entire space task group. The real disappointment came several weeks later when the Russians launched Yuri Gagarin into orbit and recovered him after one revolution. With added resolve and the permission of the President's Scientific Advisory Committee, the animal tests were cancelled, a test flight of the redstone was completed, and MR3 was given a green light. After several launch attempts had been scrubbed because of weather, on Friday, May 5th, 1961, Shepherd was again ready to fly. NASA had decided to allow the media, including television, to cover the launch in real time, putting tremendous pressure on everyone involved — but this decision turned out to be far wiser than all of us could have imagined. The launch was scheduled for 7 a.m., but clouds and rain covered the cape. We decided to press on, have Alan enter the capsule, and wait for the weather to clear. The picture I had on my console of Shepard exiting the trailer at the pad with searchlights shining on him and his silver space suit is still emblazoned in my mind. It was one of the most exciting moments of our lives. We all waited, and finally the weather began to clear, and we picked up the count. As we reached T-minus-two minutes, the magic point in a count in those days, Stan White began giving me Alan's vital signs, and he reported his heart rate was increasing and near liftoff reached 180. He was not the only one whose adrenaline was flowing. I looked down to make some notes and suddenly noticed the microphone on my headset was missing. I was about to have it replaced when I realized it was still there, but I was shaking so hard that it appeared as a blur in my eyes. and his health. He performed exactly as you would expect the finest test pilot to do, and his entry and recovery were equally spectacular. The Navy helicopter retrieved Shepherd and his spacecraft, and history was made. The reaction of the country to this brief suborbital flight was incredible, and Shepherd had become the hero he had not set out to be. The world praised the US for its success, but particularly for the willingness to share it with the rest of the world as it happened. This, they reported, was in stark contrast to the Russian secrecy and failure to report their missions until they were successfully completed. The country celebrated the astronauts' accomplishment, and President Kennedy invited Shepard and his colleagues to the White House to receive the country's highest honor. The impression that Shepard's flight made on the country and the world was not overlooked by the President, and within weeks he had decided to challenge the nation with landing men on the moon and returning them safely to Earth before this decade is out. Alan Shepard had not only become the nation's first astronaut, he had inspired his country to set out on one of its greatest adventures. Alan's contribution to his country, his commitment to the space program, and his willingness to always go the last mile to show it are what made him so dear to all of us. I'd like to end with this prayer from the Episcopal Book of Common Prayer. Almighty God we remember this day before thee thy faithful servant Alan Shepard and we pray thee that having opened to him the gates of larger life thou will receive him more and more into thy joyful service that he may win with thee and thy servants everywhere the eternal victory through Jesus Christ our Lord Amen Ladies, family, guests, friends of Al's, all of us here today. Alan Shepard was many things. He was a patriot. He was a leader. He was a competitor, a fierce competitor. He was a hero. Mostly importantly to us, he was a close friend. When we seven were chosen as the first American astronauts, Al stood out, and I had first known Al several years earlier when we were both test pilots at the Naval Air Test Center at Patuxent River, Maryland. But it wasn't until the Mercury program I saw firsthand the determination, the toughness, and the courage of Alan Sheppard. Think we have to remember, as Chris referred to a moment ago, the depths of the cold war we tend to forget that sometimes and all of a sudden after sputnik america's technological superiority in this world was under serious question we tried to put up satellites we'd failed we'd beaten up we we had been beaten in the early days of the space race by a country that bragged that America now sleeps under a Soviet moon, as they twitted us. It meant something to us. Many kids of the world were going to Moscow for education instead of to our schools in this country, and nations were being affected by the propaganda that was being put out. We'd sum it up by saying it was a very, very low time for American self-esteem. The naysayers and the doubters about our nation were getting very, very serious attention. But Al brought us back. He brought us back because of his leadership in the mercury program. He brought us back because he carried the American questing spirit on his shoulders into the heavens. He brought us back because Al took that challenge from the Soviet, not only as the patriot he was. Al took that personally. All seven of us watched some of those early rocket tests and we watched some of them fail and occasionally in very spectacular fashion. We could spend a couple of hours here this afternoon talking about our experiences and watching some of the things down there and then people saying and you're going to go up on one of those things. But that didn't deter us. And especially it did not deter Al. Named his spacecraft Freedom 7, we were free to name our own spacecraft back in those days, Freedom 7, his view of where this whole program stood in relationship to openness around the world, what we stood for. Fact is he sat in Freedom 7 through yet another delay before his historic Mercury mission. He was very anxious to get going, and we heard an anxious-to-get-going Al suggest, why don't you fix your little problem and light this candle? And he wasn't making light, but he, that one moment eloquently portrays Al as a, Al's dedication to getting the program going. America's lost one of its true adventures, someone whose entire life was dictated by the American questing spirit. And Alan and Scott and Gordo and Wally and I have lost more than a friend. We've lost another brother. The National Aviation Hall of Fame every year has an induction ceremony that traditionally closes with the reading of what is without a doubt the single best known poem among aviators all over the world. It was written by an American who joined the Royal Canadian Air Force and was killed at the age of 19 flying a Spitfire during the Battle of Britain. the words have an even more special meaning to us today than they did in 1977 when the name of Alan Shepard was inscribed in the Aviation Hall of Fame the poem is titled High Flight oh I have slipped the surly bonds of earth and danced the skies on laughter silvered wings sunward I've climbed and joined the tumbling mirth of sun-split clouds and done a hundred things you have not dreamed of wheeled and soared and swung high in the sunlit silence hovering there I've chased the shouting wind along and flung my eager craft through footless halls of air up the long, delirious, burning blue I've topped the windswept heights with easy grace where never lark or even eagle flew blue and while with silent lifting mind I have trod the high untrespass sanctity of space, put out my hand and touch the face of God." Even as we meet here today, Al is now, right now, this very minute, experiencing that ultimate of all times high flight but here we will all miss him very much louise and the family our thoughts and prayers with you. It has been nearly four decades since I first met Al Shepherd. Shortly after that, I first came to know him early in our training when I rode in his Corvette from Langley Field to Johnsville for some early centrifuge training. By the time we got to Johnsville I realized I was in the company of a dedicated naval officer, a unique and capable aviator, a born leader, and a serious competitor in anything he decided he wanted to do. The placard in his corvette on the dashboard, saying, especially made for Alan B. Shepherd, only added to my awe and respect for this multi-talented fellow. I never asked, and that is why I never found out, how he came by that special compensation from General Motors. But I always wondered. for a long time both Al and I lived with some names that we were not particularly fond of His was Bartlett, mine is Malcolm. We fell into the custom after a while of always addressing each other by those names. In keeping with that custom, I will now say my hat's off to you Bartlett. Thank you for all you have done for the Navy, for the space program, and for your country. It is an honor and a privilege to have known you. Weezer, family, friends, and some military people, I might add. I would like to recommend that we all think of as Rear Allen Bartlett Shepard Jr., U.S. Navy, Yankee from New Hampshire, Naval Academy graduate, Black Shoe, Cogswell in the Pacific, Brown Shoe, Naval Aviator, Aircraft Carriers, Test Pilot, Astronaut, and a very generous man. When we were brought, I don't think we reordered, I think we volunteered, to Langley Air Force Base, we suddenly realized we didn't have any more uniforms, they were gone. We were going to be civilians from then on. Our budget was rather tough, because I don't recall, I was talking to Joe, my wife, just the other day, I don't recall ever going to work without wearing a uniform. This was a big transition for us. So we sat in this very humble office, seven of us, with Nancy Lowe sitting outside, guarding the door as our secretary, wondering what the heck we're doing here. The seven of us bonded almost immediately. We left on different parts of the continent, literally, to check on engineering drawings, on engineering plans, on engineering symposiums, medical tests in addition to the original ones we had, briefings, simulations. We were kind of busy. and each Friday we came back and debriefed each other so we knew what was going on. It was the only way we could cover the whole ballpark. With that we began to realize that each of us were participating in whatever flight we had. But as I watched, I saw Alan Sheppard stand out. I made the mistake of voting for him on that pier thing now that I think about it. As a result, I could see Al was becoming a leader. here. We had our Mercury program go on, and time came on and Deke Slayton was to fly, who was remembered here not too long ago. Rather tough to come back again here, but thinking of Deke, we realized that if he was going to be grounded we better have him in charge. We didn't want an Admiral coming down to take care of us and be responsible for us. We wanted one of our own. After Mercury, Allen was due to fly Germany and was grounded because of Meniere's syndrome, an ear problem, grounded for almost a decade. My last recollection of Alan hitting a golf ball was on Kauai, on the sixth green of Ocean Nine on the edge, he drove a ball off the edge into the Pacific Ocean, and he said, that one went miles and miles. I didn't have to take a Mulligan. You will remember Alan B. I was called Sky-Ride by him. The family, of course, we all think of, and it's kind of tough to be called Bartlett, isn't it? Started out in Washington for a whole week of mental exams, written exams. And then we went on to Lovelace Clinic. that was very interesting as they've been told to weed as many people as they cut out so we were the first of the guinea pigs if you will to come through and it was very interesting they weeding a lot of people out they were brutal but it was real adventure then we went from there to Wright-Patterson Air Force Base where we went through the physiological training where they put us on vibrators and they dunked us in ice water and they roasted us in ovens and They sealed us up in soundproof chambers and everything they could think of to do to people and really discourage them and see if they could tolerate it. And out of that then we had a real adventure in April of 59 when we were all brought out onto a stage like this and announced to the world who the seven first seven were. And boy, there were lots of cameras, lots of reporters. That was certainly most of us's really exposure to the news media and the cameras and the world of public relations. But we survived that, didn't we, Al? We got through it. And we survived the Navy Frogman School. We went through UDT training like we went through every other kind of training we could think of. We survived that one and we roasted in the Nevada Desert together. found out we could learn to get along all right in the desert situation we survived the jungles of Panama we survived the research and really the research and the running the engineering they went on on the Johnville center a few years it was brutal but it proved what how strong how capable the human body really is. We raced many miles in identical Corvettes and I'm sorry Al that I never told you that I changed the ratio in my differential and you really weren't any less a driver it's just that I cheated a little on you we spent long days and nights getting ready to get MR3 ready to go I was going to be the blockhouse communicator and we were together on the communication system in the launch and I'll never forget there was not a dry eye anywhere in the blockhouse when we launched. And I had Warner Brown and Kurt Levis right at my right elbow, and they were very excited to be able to speak to Al very briefly. And then you were my capsule communicator on my Mercury flight. Well, we had lots of good flying, lots of good times together, Lots of good tests and a lot of things going on. And in thinking of Stu and Alan, I'm reminded of an event that happened as we came up from the lunar surface. You seem to have lost a little weight since the last time I saw you. I'm somewhat sure that last week, Stuart might have repeated almost those same words. And he smiled in an inimitable way and said, Yeah, Ed, I think we are. I want to pay tribute to him and what a privilege it was to serve with Alan Shepard. and I'm sure that wherever it is that astronaut and explorers go when we depart this realm that Alan and Sue Deacon Gus, Roger, Ed Elliot, Charlie C.C., Jack, Jim, and Ron pioneering and exploring and doing things that one day we will all be doing together again. Farewell and thanks a lot. Louise, det Shepard family, distinguished ladies and gentlemen, I first met Al Shepard when he and I were part of the original Mercury candidate group. Of course, I knew of him through his work he had done at the Naval Air Test Center. Al offered me a ride in his Corvette from the hotel to the Dolly Madison house, where we were briefed by Project Mercury. And I thought to myself, this is one naval officer who really has it made. How much does one of these cost? I asked him. And he replied, if you got to ask, you can't afford to own one. But Al was a natural born leader, The type that people want to emulate and follow. And sure enough, it wasn't long before a lot of us were driving Corvettes. Al's legacy as a pioneer in our space program is firmly etched in the history books. He was fiercely competitive and won the position to be the first American in space. He had the motivation and the perseverance to hang in there during eight years of being grounded before he finally flew on Apollo 14 and landed on the moon in a place called Vromaro. When that opportunity was earlier denied me, I could not think of a more appropriate person to take my place than Alan B. Shepard. Al's legacy in space is a thing of the past, a legacy future generations can reflect on when they want to reminisce about the early heroes of space exploration. But Al Shepard left another legacy, one that did not die with him, a legacy that is alive, growing, and prosperous. He was the driving force behind the establishment by the Mercury 7 astronauts of the Astronaut Scholarship Foundation. It started out, modestly enough, in 1986 with a distribution of $1,000 to seven aspiring future engineers and scientists. But, just recently, the foundation distributed $8,500 to over 17 students. Today, I would like to introduce to you a young lady, Miss Lisa Beason. She is an early participant of the scholarship program. having received three scholarships is now a member of the board of directors of the foundation and who is forever grateful to its chairman Alan Shepard. Admiral Alan B. Shepard, Jr., some of you knew him simply as Al Shepard. When I was putting together my thoughts for today I was somewhat uncertain how I wanted to refer to Alan Shepherd because he was simultaneously one of the greatest heroes in American history and also one of the most approachable and friendly people I have known. I'm here to pay tribute to Alan Shepherd today because of the tremendous impact that he had on my life and on the lives of the other 105 people who have, so far, received the astronaut scholarship. Everyone knows about Alan's incredible accomplishments as the first American to fly in space, his walk on the Moon and the other public achievements throughout his career in the space program and in the Navy. However, since 1984, Alan worked on something which was not as widely known but which I that I think will prove to be his greatest legacy. That is, the Astronaut Scholarship Foundation. Even among people who have achieved great goals, Allan stands out because he continued to contribute to the greatness of America up through the last days of his life. It was his dedication to the Astronaut Scholarship Foundation which made it into the solid organization that it is today. Today, he helped it grow from its beginnings of awarding just $7,000 in 1986 to today, we award over $144,000 annually in the form of 17 scholarships that go to some of the top science and engineering students in the nation. He never rested on his past accomplishments. I was always impressed with the amount of time, effort, and caring that he put into the Scholarship Foundation. He viewed it as his way, along with the other astronauts, of continuing to strengthen America's position and capabilities in science and engineering. And it worked. The Scholarship winners received not only a monetary award, all of the current recipients and the alumni receive an annual invitation to meet astronauts from the Mercury, Gemini, Apollo, Skylab and Space Shuttle programs, and to meet each other. It is through these annual meetings that a strong network of scientists and engineers is being formed. Individually and together, they are making advances on many of today's frontiers in science and technology. It is also at these annual meetings where so many of the astronaut scholars have been inspired by Alan Shepard. It was obvious how much he cared about the scholarship winners when he met with them. We were all so thrilled to talk to him, and I loved the way he took a genuine interest in the lives of the students and alumni. This group of young scientists and engineers is lucky to have met him. program. I would not have achieved the success I have experienced today without Allen's dedication to this scholarship program. The scholarship was the most significant source of funding for my college education. And then after graduation when I started volunteering with the foundation it was the support and encouragement of Allen and the other astronauts which gave me the confidence needed to advance quickly in my career in engineering at Westinghouse. Without Without that positive feedback, I honestly believe I would not be in the position I am today. It's difficult to describe the impact that he made. Then during the last eight years as I came to know Allen and serving with him on the board of directors of the scholarship foundation for the past couple of years, he always made me feel like I could do anything beyond my wildest dreams. All of the astronaut scholars will be forever grateful to Allen Shepherd for everything that he did for us. these simple words can't express the difference he made to Louise and the entire Shepard family I think you have a wonderful guardian angle watching over you now and I think I've now discovered the answer to the uncertainty that I posed before about what's the best way to refer to Alan Shepard I think I'll just call him my friend Louise, Shepard family, and all the friends of Alan Shepard here today. Before I make my personal remarks, I'd like to read you a letter from the President. Dear Mrs. Shepard, Hillary and I were deeply saddened to learn of your husband's death and our hearts go out to you. Alan Shepard was a true hero. Courage, determination, and an irrepressible sense of humor, he blazed a trail for our nation into the unknown and sparked the dreams of a generation. As the first American in space and one of only twelve to walk on the moon, he made an enormous contributions to our space program and expanded the reach of human knowledge. I hope you will take comfort in knowing that your husband holds a special place not only in our nation's history but also in the hearts of his fellow Americans. His death is a great loss for us all. We are keeping you and your family in our thoughts and prayers sincerely, Bill Clinton. I know it can be done, that it's important for it to be done, and I want to do it. These simple but poignant words were written in Life magazine in 1959. The author captured NASA's mind, body and soul. The author was NASA's mind, body and soul, Alan Shepard. Alan dared to dream. He believed in his heart that the NASA family had the talent, courage and focus to do what others said we in America couldn't do. and he wanted to be first. He, like the other astronauts of Mercury 7, wanted to lead the way. But not just in the early days. Everyone knows about Alan Shepard's historic ride on Freedom 7 and his golf shot during Apollo 14. But he did so much more. He was a fighter who always fought. for our nation and its space program. He always fought for the future. I remember one instance in 1993 when the Space program was in big trouble in the Congress. Allen, always a competitor, went to work. He wrote editorials and made phone calls on the upcoming vote on the nation's Space program. John Glenn can tell you that members of Congress get a lot of phone calls from a lot of important people, but when Alan Shepard was on the line, you always picked up the phone. Many people predicted a resounding loss and many people predicted an end to space exploration for decades to come. America won its space program by a single vote that year. Ever since, the margin of victory has increased, and ever since, the space program has gotten stronger. We win in large part because Alan Shepard knew it could be done, that it was important that it be done, and he wanted to do it. Alan was not only a fighter, but a visionary. Alan told me on many occasions about his vision for Mars exploration. His eyes would light up. No surprise, he personally wanted to go and he wanted to be first. I tell you today, Allen, America will go to Mars and when we do it, it will be because we, like you, knew it could be done, that it was important that it be done, and that we wanted to do it. That's the way Allen thought. he knew no other way and now NASA thinks the same way. Alan Shepard was our mind. Before the Mercury 7 were named not too many people really knew about our space program in America or the world. NASA was around, but we were really a bunch of nerdy engineers and scientists, talented and hardworking nerds nonetheless. But then Alan Shepard and the Mercury Seven came along. They were intense, determined, and willing to risk their lives to open the space frontier for our country. They gave America's space program a real face, and they gave our nation what all nations and what all people need heroes. Genuine, bonafide heroes. The Mercury seven were the beginning and Al was the first. At a time when our nation's confidence was down, he had the courage to climb a track on top that not completely tested redstone missile and opened the space frontier. He was our mind and our body. That first trip to space lasted only 15 minutes, but the space Alan Shepard occupies in our history, in our nation's consciousness, in our hearts, will last forever. After all, it's a very high compliment when someone wants to grow up to be like you. Literally millions of children wanted to grow up like Alan Shepard. Older kids like me still do because when he lifted off, he lifted our spirits and he inspired us to always explore the unknown and discover what's possible, to always think of the future, to always do our part. Alan was our soul. The poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow once wrote, where a star quenched on high for ages would its light, still traveling downward from the sky, shine on our mortal sight. So when a great man dies for years behind his ken, the light he leaves behind him lies upon the paths of men. Alan Shepard lived to travel towards stars quenched on high. Today he is a star quenched on high and his spirit shines on. It shines on Louise and his family. It shines on America and it shines on a space program that whether the moon, Mars, or beyond promises to live by the words I know it can be done that it's important for it to be done and I want to do it. Alan Shepard, a brilliant star in the heavens will forever shine on us, NASA's mind, body, and soul. It's I'll be here in sunshine or in shadow. Oh, Danny boy, oh, Danny boy, I love you so. We're here today to honor one of our comrades. He, like the others that we've commemorated here with these trees, have been a part of this great adventure we call Spaceflight, but Alan Shepard did much more, he led the way. He represented the very best this country could offer. We knew him, of course, as a husband, a father, and a friend, but Alan was much more than that. He has been, is, and always will be a part of our achievements and accomplishments in space. He's been with us each step of the way. There are those that would say that our colleague is not with us today. That is not true. If you'll bear with me, I would like to read you the words that were written by one of the individuals that we commemorate with a tree in this grove of trees. His words that he wrote I think apply very well today. Do not stand at my grave and wait for me, I am not there, I do not sleep. I am a thousand winds that blow, I am a diamond glint on fallen snow. I am the scent of ripened grain, I am the stars that shine at night, I am the summer sunshine bright. So do not stand at my grave and cry, for I am not there for I did not die." Before we have a prayer, I'd like to share with you two special experiences that we had with Alan.
Many knew him as a famous astronaut, most of you here as a friend, a colleague.
We knew him more as a family man, as the devoted husband of Louise and the father of Laura, Julie and Alice.
Our two daughters are the same age as his youngest two.
They have always been the best of friends.
Many times we saw Alan carrying the girl's dolls and tea sets
from their house to ours and from ours to theirs.
Our girls regarded Alan more as their friend's daddy
and not as a world famous figure.
So when he offered to fly them along with his three to Maine,
to summer camp, we were thrilled for their sakes.
We thought, just think what the children can tell their children,
that Alan Shepard had flown them to Maine.
As parents, that was our perspective.
Having been a World War II B-17 pilot,
I immediately asked him
how are you going to manage
five rambunctious little girls on the plane?
He replied, it's very simple
if they get restless
I'll just go up to 10,000 feet
and they will all go to sleep.
We were at the local airport
when they took off.
They did have some engine trouble,
so they flew directly to Hobby to get it repaired.
Eventually, they took off for Maine.
En route, they made other stops to refuel.
Hours later, they arrived at Barnstable Airport in Massachusetts.
Upon arrival, one of our little girls called me on the telephone
and implored,
oh daddy,
please,
please,
next time
can we go commercial?
Now on to a more serious remembrance.
After his return from the moon,
my wife gingerly asked him
Alan,
he replied very solemnly,
oh, yes, we thought about that.
My friends, this is genuine courage and bravery.
This is a tribute to the courage, bravery and heroism of Alan Shepard,
and it is a tribute to all of the astronauts.
These are brave and brave of the extraterrestrials.
brave men, I am sure I speak for all Americans. We are proud of you, and we admire and appreciate
your courage and bravery in this space effort. I could give no more sacred prayer than the
following verses from the Bible. Psalms. Whither shall I go from thy spirit, or whither
shall I flee from thy presence.
If I ascend up into heaven,
thou art there.
If I make my bed in hell,
behold, thou art there.
If I take the wings of the morning
and dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea,
even there shall thy hand lead me
and thy right hand shall hold me.
As a young boy, who was a Sunday School student, Alan Shepard learned a prayer.
His wife Louise wants his friends to hear this prayer, as he came to know it.
She stated that this prayer had a profound influence on his life.
This is the prayer by Mary Baker Eddy.
Thy kingdom come.
Let the reign of divine truth, life, and love be established in me
and rule out of me all sin.
And may thy word enrich the affections of all mankind and govern them.
And from the scriptures.
Simon Peter answered him, Lord, we believe and are sure that thou art that Christ, the
son of the living God.
And this is the promise that he hath promised us, even eternal life.
Good afternoon, Louise, the Sheppard family, ladies and gentlemen.
It's wonderful to look out in that audience and almost recognize every face there.
We're here this afternoon to remember Alan Sheppard as a friend and as a colleague,
one who we all admire and will find impossible to replace.
In 1959, when the United States decided to fly man in space, the newly chartered NASA
needed a number of men to fly their Mercury spacecraft.
The requirements for these aviators and soon-to-be-called astronauts were reasonable to be straightforward
and unambiguous.
unsurchemistry. A number of us in the Space Task Group had come from the world of airplane
flight tests, and we recognized that we needed experienced test pilots who understood the
rigors of testing the unknown and were accustomed to putting their lives in jeopardy every time
they flew. They had to be prepared to do their job regardless of the threatening circumstances
they might find themselves in.
We also wanted them to understand the engineering design required of this new flying machine
and to be able to participate in its development.
Alan Shepard volunteered to be one of the men we were looking for.
He came to this new challenge because in his mind spaceflight was the next step in man's
quest to fly higher and faster and as a navy test pilot, this was his kind of business.
He did not come into the space program looking for glory.
Indeed, many of his peers looked with scorn on what they thought was a step backward in
test flying and refused to consider themselves as test specimens for a highly experimental
program with a questionable future.
year. In fact, if you listen to the so called medical community who were advising NASA in
1959, the test pilots who were criticizing Project Mercury were justified in their evaluation.
The great majority of the doctors believed that man's reaction to this new environment
of zero gravity and a perfect vacuum would cause disorientation, nausea, loss of sight,
and other dire ailments, and as a result, might be totally incapable of doing work,
much less conducting the complex and intricate task we were expecting them to carry out.
Fortunately, Bob Gilruth, and those of us who work for him, believed that a qualified
test pilot, with proper training, could most likely accomplish the same tasks and space
that they had been conducting in high performance airplanes.
We wanted the men who were going to fly to be an integral part of the spacecraft, just
as they had been in the airplanes they flew.
As the first man flight approached, the competition for being first among the seven astronauts
became very intense.
As in any group greater than one, it was difficult to choose who should be selected.
Bob Gilruth, a man who never received the proper credit for being the father of man
in space flight, met with the astronauts and asked them to write a brief essay on who and
why they should be chosen to fly the first flight, excluding themselves.
From this interesting and provocative exercise, and with the advice and consent of his staff,
He picked Alan Shepard to fly the first manned mercury redstone flight
These were heady times
And Alan already charged
Doubled his efforts to train for the 15-minute sub-ortal flight
Unfortunately
Shepherd's flight had to be preceded by the flight of a chimpanzee
Although we were six we successfully launched and recovered ham
the hot engine of the redstone
caused an early shutdown which precipitated an escape rocket separation,
subjecting him to 17G and giving gave the false impression that the animal
had failed to perform. The demand of further redstone testing and a
requirement to test a large number of animals on the Johnsonville centrifuge
postponed Shepherd's flight. Shepherd was extremely disappointed and agitated by
the delay as was the entire space task group. The real disappointment came several weeks
later when the Russians launched Yuri Gagarin into orbit and recovered him after one revolution.
With added resolve and the permission of the President's Scientific Advisory Committee,
the animal tests were cancelled, a test flight of the redstone was completed, and MR3 was
given a green light. After several launch attempts had been scrubbed because of
weather, on Friday, May 5th, 1961, Shepherd was again ready to fly. NASA had decided
to allow the media, including television, to cover the launch in real time, putting
tremendous pressure on everyone involved — but this decision turned out to be far
wiser than all of us could have imagined.
The launch was scheduled for 7 a.m., but clouds and rain covered the cape.
We decided to press on, have Alan enter the capsule, and wait for the weather to clear.
The picture I had on my console of Shepard exiting the trailer at the pad with searchlights
shining on him and his silver space suit is still emblazoned in my mind. It was one of the
most exciting moments of our lives. We all waited, and finally the weather began to clear,
and we picked up the count. As we reached T-minus-two minutes, the magic point in a count in
those days, Stan White began giving me Alan's vital signs, and he reported his heart rate was
increasing and near liftoff reached 180. He was not the only one whose adrenaline was flowing.
I looked down to make some notes and suddenly noticed the microphone on my headset was missing.
I was about to have it replaced when I realized it was still there,
but I was shaking so hard that it appeared as a blur in my eyes.
and his
health.
He performed exactly as you would expect the finest test pilot to do, and his entry
and recovery were equally spectacular.
The Navy helicopter retrieved Shepherd and his spacecraft, and history was made.
The reaction of the country to this brief suborbital flight was incredible, and Shepherd
had become the hero he had not set out to be.
The world praised the US for its success, but particularly for the willingness to share
it with the rest of the world as it happened.
This, they reported, was in stark contrast to the Russian secrecy and failure to report
their missions until they were successfully completed.
The country celebrated the astronauts' accomplishment,
and President Kennedy invited Shepard and his colleagues to the White House
to receive the country's highest honor.
The impression that Shepard's flight made on the country and the world
was not overlooked by the President,
and within weeks he had decided to challenge the nation
with landing men on the moon and returning them safely to Earth
before this decade is out.
Alan Shepard had not only become the nation's first astronaut,
he had inspired his country to set out on one of its greatest adventures.
Alan's contribution to his country, his commitment to the space program,
and his willingness to always go the last mile to show it are what made him so dear to all of us.
I'd like to end with this prayer from the Episcopal Book of Common Prayer.
Almighty God
we remember this day
before thee thy faithful servant
Alan Shepard
and we pray thee that having
opened to him the gates of larger life
thou will receive him
more and more into thy joyful service
that he may win
with thee and thy servants everywhere
the eternal victory
through Jesus Christ our Lord
Amen
Ladies, family, guests, friends of Al's, all of us here today.
Alan Shepard was many things.
He was a patriot.
He was a leader.
He was a competitor, a fierce competitor.
He was a hero.
Mostly importantly to us, he was a close friend.
When we seven were chosen as the first American astronauts,
Al stood out, and I had first known Al several years earlier
when we were both test pilots at the Naval Air Test Center
at Patuxent River, Maryland.
But it wasn't until the Mercury program I saw firsthand the determination,
the toughness, and the courage of Alan Sheppard.
Think we have to remember, as Chris referred to a moment ago,
the depths of the cold war we tend to forget that sometimes and all of a sudden after sputnik america's
technological superiority in this world was under serious question we tried to put up satellites
we'd failed we'd beaten up we we had been beaten in the early days of the space race by a country
that bragged that America now sleeps under a Soviet moon,
as they twitted us.
It meant something to us.
Many kids of the world were going to Moscow for education
instead of to our schools in this country,
and nations were being affected by the propaganda
that was being put out.
We'd sum it up by saying it was a very, very low time
for American self-esteem.
The naysayers and the doubters about our nation were getting very, very serious attention.
But Al brought us back.
He brought us back because of his leadership in the mercury program.
He brought us back because he carried the American questing spirit on his shoulders
into the heavens.
He brought us back because Al took that challenge from the Soviet, not only as the patriot he
was. Al took that personally. All seven of us watched some of those early rocket tests
and we watched some of them fail and occasionally in very spectacular fashion. We could spend
a couple of hours here this afternoon talking about our experiences and watching some of
the things down there and then people saying and you're going to go up on one of those
things. But that didn't deter us. And especially it did not deter Al. Named his spacecraft
Freedom 7, we were free to name our own spacecraft back in those days, Freedom 7,
his view of where this whole program stood in relationship to openness around the world,
what we stood for.
Fact is he sat in Freedom 7 through yet another delay before his historic Mercury mission.
He was very anxious to get going, and we heard an anxious-to-get-going Al suggest,
why don't you fix your little problem and light this candle?
And he wasn't making light, but he, that one moment eloquently portrays Al as a, Al's
dedication to getting the program going.
America's lost one of its true adventures, someone whose entire life was dictated by
the American questing spirit.
And Alan and Scott and Gordo and Wally and I have lost more than a friend.
We've lost another brother.
The National Aviation Hall of Fame every year has an induction ceremony that traditionally
closes with the reading of what is without a doubt the single best known poem among aviators
all over the world.
It was written by an American who joined the Royal Canadian Air Force and was killed at
the age of 19 flying a Spitfire during the Battle of Britain.
the words have an even more special meaning to us today than they did in 1977 when the name of
Alan Shepard was inscribed in the Aviation Hall of Fame the poem is titled High Flight
oh I have slipped the surly bonds of earth and danced the skies on laughter silvered wings
sunward I've climbed and joined the tumbling mirth of sun-split clouds
and done a hundred things you have not dreamed of
wheeled and soared and swung high in the sunlit silence
hovering there I've chased the shouting wind along
and flung my eager craft through footless halls of air
up the long, delirious, burning blue
I've topped the windswept heights with easy grace
where never lark or even eagle flew
blue and while with silent lifting mind I have trod the high untrespass sanctity of space,
put out my hand and touch the face of God."
Even as we meet here today, Al is now, right now, this very minute, experiencing that ultimate
of all times high flight but here we will all miss him very much louise and the family our
thoughts and prayers with you.
It has been nearly four decades since I first met Al Shepherd. Shortly after that, I first
came to know him early in our training when I rode in his Corvette from Langley Field to Johnsville
for some early centrifuge training. By the time we got to Johnsville I realized I was in the company
of a dedicated naval officer, a unique and capable aviator, a born leader, and a serious
competitor in anything he decided he wanted to do. The placard in his corvette on the
dashboard, saying, especially made for Alan B. Shepherd, only added to my awe and respect
for this multi-talented fellow. I never asked, and that is why I never found out, how he
came by that special compensation from General Motors. But I always wondered.
for a long time both Al and I lived with some names that we were not particularly fond of
His was Bartlett, mine is Malcolm.
We fell into the custom after a while of always addressing each other by those names.
In keeping with that custom, I will now say my hat's off to you Bartlett.
Thank you for all you have done for the Navy, for the space program,
and for your country.
It is an honor and a privilege to have known you.
Weezer, family, friends, and some military people, I might add.
I would like to recommend that we all think of as Rear Allen Bartlett Shepard Jr., U.S.
Navy, Yankee from New Hampshire, Naval Academy graduate, Black Shoe, Cogswell in the Pacific,
Brown Shoe, Naval Aviator, Aircraft Carriers, Test Pilot, Astronaut, and a very generous
man.
When we were brought, I don't think we reordered, I think we volunteered, to Langley Air Force Base, we suddenly realized we didn't have any more uniforms, they were gone.
We were going to be civilians from then on.
Our budget was rather tough, because I don't recall, I was talking to Joe, my wife, just the other day, I don't recall ever going to work without wearing a uniform.
This was a big transition for us.
So we sat in this very humble office, seven of us,
with Nancy Lowe sitting outside,
guarding the door as our secretary,
wondering what the heck we're doing here.
The seven of us bonded almost immediately.
We left on different parts of the continent,
literally, to check on engineering drawings,
on engineering plans, on engineering symposiums,
medical tests in addition to the original ones we had,
briefings, simulations.
We were kind of busy.
and each Friday we came back and debriefed each other so we knew what was going on.
It was the only way we could cover the whole ballpark.
With that we began to realize that each of us were participating in whatever flight we had.
But as I watched, I saw Alan Sheppard stand out.
I made the mistake of voting for him on that pier thing now that I think about it.
As a result, I could see Al was becoming a leader.
here. We had our Mercury program go on, and time came on and Deke Slayton was to fly,
who was remembered here not too long ago. Rather tough to come back again here, but

us. We wanted one of our own. After Mercury, Allen was due to fly Germany and was grounded
because of Meniere's syndrome, an ear problem, grounded for almost a decade.
Dic asked Al, would you help me out and be in charge of the astronaut office?
We had two great leaders.
We've lost two of our great leaders.
We're down to four now.
We've lost Gus on the launch pad.
The brotherhood we had will endure forever.
It's that interesting part of Allen Shepard that came to light when he got to the Moon
finally, and he hit that ball for miles and miles.
My last recollection of Alan hitting a golf ball was on Kauai, on the sixth green of Ocean
Nine on the edge, he drove a ball off the edge into the Pacific Ocean, and he said,
that one went miles and miles.
I didn't have to take a Mulligan.

children of grandchildren did Alan. Of course the whole family. Here I love and

Louise and family.
I sort of had a message for Al today.
We had a lot of adventures together, Al.
We're in the first group of six contestants.
Started out in Washington for a whole week of mental exams, written exams.
And then we went on to Lovelace Clinic.
that was very interesting as they've been told to weed as many people as they

and it was very interesting they weeding a lot of people out they were brutal
but it was real adventure then we went from there to Wright-Patterson Air Force

on vibrators and they dunked us in ice water and they roasted us in ovens and
They sealed us up in soundproof chambers and everything they could think of to do to people
and really discourage them and see if they could tolerate it.
And out of that then we had a real adventure in April of 59 when we were all brought out onto a stage like this
and announced to the world who the seven first seven were.
And boy, there were lots of cameras, lots of reporters.
That was certainly most of us's really exposure to the news media and the cameras and the world of public relations.
But we survived that, didn't we, Al?
We got through it.
And we survived the Navy Frogman School.
We went through UDT training like we went through every other kind of training we could think of.
We survived that one and we roasted in the Nevada Desert together.
found out we could learn to get along all right in the desert situation we survived the jungles of Panama
we survived the research and really the research and the running the engineering they went on on the Johnville center a few years
it was brutal but it proved what how strong how capable the human body really

Well, we had lots of good flying,
lots of good times together,
Lots of good tests and a lot of things going on.
Now you're up there in that big hangar in the sky having a lot of good flights

But we'll be there before long so we'll try some of that flying ourselves.
My best to all of you and we'll miss Al.

Good afternoon.
It's my privilege but sad duty to represent the Apollo 14 crew on
this occasion.
I know Stu would have wanted to be here, but his wonderful family has
come over to be with us for this occasion.
And in thinking of Stu and Alan, I'm reminded of an event that happened as we came up from
the lunar surface.
If you remember the tapes, as we came into sight of the command module, you could hear
hear Stuart's voice come over the radio and say, hello down there, fearless one. What
are you doing down there? You seem to have lost a little weight since the last time I
saw you. I'm somewhat sure that last week, Stuart might have repeated almost those same
words.
I am a privileged that Alan chose Stewart and I had to go with him. He was a wonderful
ougful teammate, colleague, leader, boss.
I remember on the final day of our simulation of the lunar landing before the flight, when
the team had thrown virtually every malfunction they could find at us and we successfully
when it was over, I turned to him and said,
Congratulations, boss, I think we're ready to go.
And he smiled in an inimitable way and said,
Yeah, Ed, I think we are.
I want to pay tribute to him and what a privilege it was
to serve with Alan Shepard.
and I'm sure that
wherever it is that astronaut and explorers
go when we depart this realm
that Alan and Sue
Deacon Gus, Roger, Ed
Elliot, Charlie
C.C., Jack, Jim, and Ron pioneering and exploring and doing things that one day we will all

Farewell and thanks a lot.
Louise, det Shepard family, distinguished ladies and gentlemen, I first met Al Shepard
when he and I were part of the original Mercury candidate group.
Of course, I knew of him through his work he had done at the Naval Air Test Center.
Al offered me a ride in his Corvette from the hotel to the Dolly Madison house,
where we were briefed by Project Mercury.
And I thought to myself,
this is one naval officer who really has it made.
How much does one of these cost? I asked him.
And he replied, if you got to ask, you can't afford to own one.
But Al was a natural born leader,
The type that people want to emulate and follow.
And sure enough, it wasn't long before a lot of us were driving Corvettes.
Al's legacy as a pioneer in our space program is firmly etched in the history books.
He was fiercely competitive and won the position to be the first American in space.
He had the motivation and the perseverance to hang in there
during eight years of being grounded before he finally flew on Apollo 14
and landed on the moon in a place called Vromaro.
When that opportunity was earlier denied me,
I could not think of a more appropriate person to take my place than Alan B. Shepard.
Al's legacy in space is a thing of the past,
a legacy future generations can reflect on
when they want to reminisce about the early heroes of space exploration.
But Al Shepard left another legacy, one that did not die with him,
a legacy that is alive, growing, and prosperous.
He was the driving force behind the establishment
by the Mercury 7 astronauts of the Astronaut Scholarship Foundation.
It started out, modestly enough, in 1986 with a distribution of $1,000 to seven aspiring
future engineers and scientists.
But, just recently, the foundation distributed $8,500 to over 17 students.
Today, I would like to introduce to you a young lady, Miss Lisa Beason.
She is an early participant of the scholarship program.
having received three scholarships is now a member of the board of directors of
the foundation and who is forever grateful to its chairman Alan Shepard.
Admiral Alan B. Shepard, Jr., some of you knew him simply as Al Shepard. When I
was putting together my thoughts for today I was somewhat uncertain how I
wanted to refer to Alan Shepherd because he was simultaneously one of the
greatest heroes in American history and also one of the most approachable and
friendly people I have known. I'm here to pay tribute to Alan Shepherd today
because of the tremendous impact that he had on my life and on the lives of the
other 105 people who have, so far, received the astronaut scholarship.
Everyone knows about Alan's incredible accomplishments as the first American to fly in space, his
walk on the Moon and the other public achievements throughout his career in the space program
and in the Navy.
However, since 1984, Alan worked on something which was not as widely known but which I
that I think will prove to be his greatest legacy.
That is, the Astronaut Scholarship Foundation.
Even among people who have achieved great goals,
Allan stands out because he continued to contribute
to the greatness of America up through the last days
of his life.
It was his dedication to the Astronaut Scholarship Foundation
which made it into the solid organization that it is today.
Today, he helped it grow from its beginnings of awarding just $7,000 in 1986 to today,
we award over $144,000 annually in the form of 17 scholarships that go to some of the
top science and engineering students in the nation.
He never rested on his past accomplishments.
I was always impressed with the amount of time, effort, and caring that he put into
the Scholarship Foundation.
He viewed it as his way, along with the other astronauts, of continuing to strengthen America's
position and capabilities in science and engineering.
And it worked.
The Scholarship winners received not only a monetary award, all of the current recipients
and the alumni receive an annual invitation to meet astronauts from the Mercury, Gemini,
Apollo, Skylab and Space Shuttle programs, and to meet each other.
It is through these annual meetings that a strong network of scientists and engineers
is being formed.
Individually and together, they are making advances on many of today's frontiers in
science and technology.
It is also at these annual meetings where so many of the astronaut scholars have been
inspired by Alan Shepard.
It was obvious how much he cared about the scholarship winners when he met with them.
We were all so thrilled to talk to him, and I loved the way he took a genuine interest
in the lives of the students and alumni.
